spt.risk-factors:
1#2012-08-28 17:29:14.0#####1#2012-08-28 17:29:14.0#Weight##100#Normal/Underweight/Overweight/#[Normal, Underweight, Overweight]#4#Normal##null@1#2012-08-28 17:29:14.0#There's no way around it. Smoking is bad for your health. Smoking harms nearly every organ of the body. http://www.nlm.nih.gov####1#2012-08-28 17:29:14.0#Smoking##100#Non Smoker/Current Smoker/#[Non Smoker, Current Smoker]#7#Non Smoker##null@1#2012-08-28 17:29:14.0#Alcohol use is a slippery slope. Moderate drinking can offer some health benefits. But it's easy to drink too heavily, leading to serious health consequences. http://www.mayoclinic.com####1#2012-08-28 17:29:14.0#Alcohol Intake##100#Non Drinker/Occasional Drinker/Regular Drinker/Excessive Drinker/#[Non Drinker, Occasional Drinker, Regular Drinker, Excessive Drinker]#8#Non Drinker##null@1#2012-08-28 17:29:14.0#Diabetes is a disease in which your blood glucose, or sugar, levels are too high. Glucose comes from the foods you eat. Insulin is a hormone that helps the glucose get into your cells to give them energy. With type 1 diabetes, your body does not make insulin. With type 2 diabetes, the more common type, your body does not make or use insulin well. Without enough insulin, the glucose stays in your blood.####1#2012-08-28 17:29:14.0#Diabetes##100#Non Diabetic/Diabetic/#[Non Diabetic, Diabetic]#9#Non Diabetic##null@1#2012-08-28 17:29:14.0#Hypertension is the term used to describe high blood pressure. Blood pressure is a measurement of the force against the walls of your arteries as your heart pumps blood through your body. High blood pressure (hypertension) is when your blood pressure is 140/90 mmHg or above most of the time. Normal blood pressure is when your blood pressure is lower than 120/80 mmHg most of the time.
http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov####1#2012-08-28 17:29:14.0#Hypertension##100#Normal/Hypertensive/#[Normal, Hypertensive]#10#Hypertensive##null@1#2012-08-28 17:29:14.0#Non-valvular atrial fibrillation refers to atrial fibrillation that does not occur in the setting of mitral valve disease such as mitral stenosis or mitral regurgitation. https://www.healthtap.com####1#2012-08-28 17:29:14.0#Non Valvular Atrial Fibrillation##100#Absent/Present/#[Absent, Present]#12#Present##null@1#2012-08-28 17:29:14.0#Contraceptives are birth control, used to prevent a woman from getting pregnant when engaging in intercourse. There are many different forms of contraceptives, some used by women and some used by men. Contraceptives such as birth control pills and condoms are widely used to prevent pregnancies. www.livestrong.com####1#2012-08-28 17:29:14.0#Contraceptives##100#Not A User/Current User/#[Not A User, Current User]#16#Current User##null@1#2012-08-28 17:29:14.0#Intracranial stenosis is the medical term for severe narrowing of a cerebral artery that restricts blood flow to areas of the brain. Such narrowing stems from focal, progressive atherosclerosis of the affected vessel. Intracranial stenosis is responsible for about 10% of strokes annually, and the rate of recurrent strokes without treatment can be alarmingly high. http://www.thebarrow.org####1#2012-08-28 17:29:14.0#Intracranial Stenosis##100#Absent/Present/#[Absent, Present]#17#Present##null@1#2012-08-28 17:29:14.0#While we are asleep, turbulent airflow can cause the tissues of the nose and throat to vibrate and give rise to snoring. Essentially, snoring is a sound resulting from turbulent airflow that causes tissues to vibrate during sleep. Frequently, people who do not regularly snore will report snoring after a viral illness, after drinking alcohol, or when taking some medications. http://www.medicinenet.com####1#2012-08-28 17:29:14.0#Snoring##100#No/Yes/#[No, Yes]#18#Yes##null@1#2012-08-28 17:29:14.0#Stroke occurred to some family members. (Hereditary characteristic of stroke.)####1#2012-08-28 17:29:14.0#Family History Stroke##100#Yes/No/#[Yes, No]#19#Yes##null@1#2012-08-28 17:29:14.0#May be Ischemic or Hemorrhagic in nature or just a mere Transient Ischemic Attack.####1#2012-08-28 17:29:14.0#Prior Stroke Or Transient Ischemic Attack##100#Absent/Present/#[Absent, Present]#11#Present##null@1#2012-08-28 17:29:14.0#The most common cause of heart disease is narrowing or blockage of the coronary arteries, the blood vessels that supply blood to the heart itself. This is called coronary artery disease and happens slowly over time. It's the major reason people have heart attacks.
Other kinds of heart problems may happen to the valves in the heart, or the heart may not pump well and cause heart failure. Some people are born with heart disease.
http://www.nlm.nih.gov####1#2012-08-28 17:29:14.0#Heart Disease##100#Absent/Present/#[Absent, Present]#13#Absent##null@1#2012-08-28 17:29:14.0#Carotid artery disease is a condition in which the carotid arteries become narrowed or blocked. When the arteries become narrowed, the condition is called carotid stenosis. www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov####1#2012-08-28 17:29:14.0#Carotid Stenosis##100#Absent/Present/#[Absent, Present]#14#Absent##null@1#2012-08-28 17:29:14.0#Peripheral arterial disease (P.A.D.) is a disease in which plaque (plak) builds up in the arteries that carry blood to your head, organs, and limbs. Plaque is made up of fat, cholesterol, calcium, fibrous tissue, and other substances in the blood. http://www.nhlbi.nih.gov####1#2012-08-28 17:29:14.0#Peripheral Arterial Disease##100#Absent/Present/#[Absent, Present]#15#Absent##null
